It is true that the church used the fear of punishment in the afterlife to control people's actions and behaviors. The concept of eternal damnation was a powerful tool of social control during the medieval period. However, to say that the church was solely concerned with maintaining its power at the expense of people's spiritual well-being would be an oversimplification. The church also provided people with a range of services, such as education, healthcare, and charity, which were essential for their well-being. The church was also an important source of community and support for many individuals during a time when life was often short and uncertain.

Moreover, while the church promoted the idea of punishment in the afterlife, it also taught the message of God's love and mercy. The concept of repentance and forgiveness was central to Christian theology, and it provided people with a means of redemption for their sins. For many people, this message of love and mercy offered hope and comfort in a world where suffering and adversity were constant realities.

Ultimately, the role of the church in medieval society was complex and multifaceted. While it certainly wielded significant power and influence, it also provided a wide range of services and support to individuals and communities. Understanding the church's role in medieval society requires a nuanced and historically informed approach that takes into account the social, cultural, and historical contexts of the time.
